He let the harpoon head slip from his grasp, and it clattered onto the stone floor, its purpose served, its terrible song sung. He was just an old man in a ruined church, and he was, at last, at peace.

The silence held, deep and profound. The air, scrubbed clean of its impossible cold and pressure, tasted of dust, old stone, and the faint, sweet scent of ozone from the burnt-out salt circle. Mr. Wong stood in the quiet ruin, a small man who felt neither small nor ruined, but simply present. The terrible weight he had carried for three decades, the psychic ballast of his guilt and his oath, had been lifted. He was light. He looked down at the Sorrow-Iron on the floor, its strange, dark metal looking inert now, a piece of forgotten history, its one great purpose fulfilled. It was just an object, a heavy, ugly thing, its story now a part of his own.

He moved, his joints protesting with a familiar, earthly ache rather than the soul-deep weariness that had plagued him. His first thought was for Rhona. He crossed the floor, his steps quiet on the dry stone, and knelt beside the crumpled form by the sarcophagus. Her breathing was shallow but steady, her face pale but peaceful in the gloom. He felt for a pulse at her neck, his fingers, now steady, finding the strong, stubborn beat of her heart. A thin line of blood trickled from a cut on her hairline, but she was alive. The pragmatic, unyielding woman had met an impossible force and had been broken by it, but she was not lost. He gently repositioned her head, a quiet gesture of care for the ally who had asked for no explanations and offered only her strength.

Then he turned to Finch. The historian was huddled in the alcove where he had sought refuge, his body curled into a tight ball, his face buried in his hands. A low, continuous sound of weeping came from him, the dry, rasping sobs of a man whose entire intellectual framework had been smashed to pieces by a single, terrifying truth. Mr. Wong approached him not as a partner in their mad venture, but as one might approach a shipwreck survivor washed up on a desolate shore. He placed a hand on Finch’s trembling shoulder. The scholar flinched violently, looking up with eyes that were no longer wild with obsession, but were wide with the clear, lucid terror of a man who has looked into the sun and seen not light, but a devouring fire. “I read the words,” he whispered, his voice a broken shell. “But I never knew their shape. I never knew the sound they made.” There was no triumph in his voice, only the horror of comprehension. He had sought the footnotes of the world’s nightmares, and the text itself had come alive to consume him.

The first rays of the true dawn, a mundane, hopeful spectrum of pink and orange, filtered through the hole in the roof, illuminating the scene of their strange, secret war. The light touched the scattered salt, the toppled candles, the silent, hulking mass of the bell. It was the light of a world that had continued, oblivious. In that growing light, Rhona stirred with a sharp intake of breath and a groan of pain. She pushed herself up slowly, one hand going to her side. “Broke a rib, I think,” she muttered, the diagnosis delivered with the same flat practicality she applied to a faulty engine. Her eyes took in the quiet church, the weeping historian, the silent sailor. Then her gaze landed on the bell. It was just a bell now, a massive, ugly piece of salvage sitting in the middle of a church. The air around it was still. “Right then,” she said, her voice strained but firm. “What do we do with that?”

An unspoken consensus formed between the three survivors. The bell could not stay. It was a battery of sorrow, and though it was now quiet, it was not empty. To leave it here would be to create a new legend, a new nexus for the curious and the broken-hearted. It had to be returned, not to its grave in the Widow’s Patch, but to a deeper, more anonymous oblivion. Rhona, moving with a stiff, painful grace, went to her lorry. Finch, his weeping subsided into a shattered, hollow silence, seemed to find a final, quiet purpose. He was no longer a hunter of myths, but their humbled custodian. He began to gather his most dangerous texts, not to study, but to seal away, his hands moving with the slow, deliberate care of a man disarming a bomb he himself had built. The great, terrible work was over; now began the quiet, necessary task of cleaning up.

The final removal of the bell was a reversal of its arrival, but a quiet, almost reverent affair. The crane lifted it from the church, its passage through the roof no longer a violation but a release. It was laid on the flatbed and covered, the weight settling onto the lorry’s springs without the accompanying psychic pressure. It was just heavy now. Finch remained at the church door, a lonely, diminished figure who would stand guard over his terrible knowledge until the end of his days. He and Mr. Wong exchanged a single, final look, the shared glance of two men who had sailed to the edge of the map together and were now parting, one to remain on that desolate shore, the other to return home.

They drove south, to a different coastline, a place of crumbling chalk cliffs and deep, fast-moving channels. There, on a lonely stretch of coast under a sky the colour of pearl, they performed the final rite. With a combination of Rhona’s crane and a steep, crumbling slipway, they let the bell of the *Empress of St. Ives* slide from the flatbed and into the sea. It entered the water with a low, heavy splash, sending circles rippling out into the calm grey water. There was no hum, no scream, no chorus of the drowned. It was the sound of a stone being dropped into a well, a final, definitive punctuation mark at the end of a century-long sentence of pain. It sank quickly, vanishing into the green depths, taking its history with it, finally at peace in a grave of its own choosing.

A month later, in a quiet cul-de-sac in Epsom, where the only salt in the air came from the gritting lorries in winter, Mr. Wong knelt on a small cushion and carefully pruned his roses. The thorns pricked his fingers, a small, clean pain that was a grounding, welcome sensation. The world felt solid under his knees, the scent of the rich, dark soil a perfume of life and continuity. The people who walked past his house were not ink sketches, but solid, complex beings, their lives a tapestry of colours he could now appreciate without the hollow ache of longing. He no longer tracked the news for whispers of impossible deaths, but he saw the headlines. Council disputes, sporting results, stories of ordinary, human chaos. The tide of monstrous sorrow had gone out, leaving the world to its own familiar, mundane griefs. He stood up, his joints creaking their familiar protest, and looked at his hands. The sailor’s knots on his knuckles were faded, blurred, the tattoos of a man from another lifetime. The weight of his oath was gone, but the memory of the voyage remained, a story he would carry not as a burden, but as a quiet, private truth. The sea had a long memory, but he had finally sailed beyond its reach. He was home.
